Title: Linking forum posts -smac-001-4-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: equivalence between newtonian and statistical mechanics
Input.posts:
The equivalence between molecular dynamics and statistical mechanics seems strange. Assume direct sampling. Newton: Each state is completely dependent on the previous state. In fact, all states are dependent on an initial state and all states are initial states for states that come after. For example, depending on velocity, some states are unreachable in small time. Direct sampling: All states are equally probable. Velocity is irrelvant and a given state is independent of previous states. In a sense, the two are opposites. Yet, they both lead to equiprobability, which is what is meant by equivalence. That is at anytime an observer looks, he will not be able to make any prediction about which state the system will be in before he looks. So, how to make sense of this? Here's what I came up with (after writing this it seems obvious). In the newtonian case it seems that an external observer might be precisely able to specify an initial state, and that observer will be able to track the state (because the observer knows newtons laws) externally so that when he looks a short time later, he'll be able make some prediction. The prediction will not be perfect because the precision of numbers is limited. The longer the system evolves without observation, the more the errors due to precision increase. The observer will be able to give a probability distribution as to where the particles might be. Eventually, that probability distribution will be come uniform, just as we have in the direct sampling case. So the equivalence. Other notes: kinetic energy must be greater than 0. Second, in the movie, the Newtonian case looks random, but if you take a snapshot of the state, you recover precise knowledge and can again predict future states to some degree. I assume this is not possible when you have millions, trillions of particles, in which case your observations consist of looking at values of macroscopic quantities such as pressure and temperature.

Simply put, if detailed balance is broken, your algorithm has not reached equilibrium, i.e. even sampling. If this were not true, you'd basically have a 'transient' term coming from the initial condition (remember the correlation time, tau).
Upvotes:

But what does that even mean? Like does it violate some physical principle?
Upvotes:
0
In a sense yes, it does violate a physical principle: That all states with equal energies should be sampled with equal probability. Now, this is not just a matter of physics. Take the pebble and the heliport. If your throws are very short, it'll take a long time to sample the whole heliport (i.e. for the pebble to have visited all parts of it), and before you do, the estimate for pi will be very poor indeed. An analogy: Suppose you want to measure the area of a dish filled with water. What you have is oil and a way to measure the height of the oil film on top of the water. The idea is then to place a predetermined amount of oil on the surface of the water and once it has spread out measure its height, from which you can determine the area, right. Now the spreading out is a rather slow, diffusive process (incidentally, equations for the Markov Chain we used can be written in terms of the diffusion equation). If you were to measure the height of the oil film immediately, it would clearly depend on where exactly on the dish you do the measurement. Once you wait long enough, the entire dish is uniformly covered in oil, and it no onger matters where you do the measurement at. What is detailed balance in terms of this analogy? It means that there can be no net flow of oil from one place to the other, i.e. that the oil has been distributed evenly. In the beginning, the oil flows from oil-rich regions to places where there is not that much oil, but eventually a backflow will build up, and these two cancel out.

Hi Eli, The numbers shown in the cells of the inhomogeneous pebble game grid are statistical weightings rather than probabilities - you could think of them as relative likelihoods or, if you prefer, divide throughout by $$\Sigma(weights)$$ (=10) to convert to probabilities. As you say the lecture illustrated the derivation of the detailed balance conditions for moves originating at a corner position.\xA0 It is clear, however, that the method could easily be extended to other starting positions, giving rise to 3 or 4 equalities of the form: $$\pi_a. p(a\rightarrow\beta) = \pi_\beta. p(\beta\rightarrow a)$$ corresponding to the 3 or 4 possible move directions. Note that all of the equalities must hold in order that the global balance condition is satisfied but we only need be concerned with one equality at a time since only one move direction is possible in any one time-step. The next stage in the lecture describes the Metropolis acceptance probability which is a mechanism to ensure that the detailed balance condition holds when $$\pi_a \neq \pi_\beta$$.\xA0 We need to choose $$p(a\rightarrow\beta)$$ and $$p(\beta\rightarrow a)$$ such that $$\pi_a / \pi_\beta = p(\beta\rightarrow a) / p(a\rightarrow\beta)$$ which is accomplished by modifying the transfer probability according to the ratio of weights as shown.

In order to observe the validity of the Metropolis acceptance probability algorithm, we need to look at a given move from both directions after the system has settled into a steady state. Take, for example, cell(0) (weight = 3.0) and cell(1) (weight = 0.5) and consider a large number (say 7000) occasions when a move between these cells has been proposed. It is 6 times more likely that the starting position will be in cell(0) than in cell(1), so: On approximately 6000 occasions the move is 0$$\rightarrow$$1 and the acceptance probability is $$min(1, \frac{0.5}{3.0}) = \frac{1}{6}$$ $$\therefore$$ move to cell(1) $$\approx$$ 1000 times, stay in cell(0) $$\approx$$ 5000 times On approximately 1000 occasions the move is 1$$\rightarrow$$0 and the acceptance probability is $$min(1, \frac{3.0}{0.5})$$ = 1 $$\therefore$$ stay in cell(1) 0 times, move to cell(0) 1000 times After the move we note that the pebble is in cell(0) on $$\approx$$ 6000 occasions and in cell(1) on $$\approx$$ 1000 occasions which is exactly what we expect.

Hi all, I just watched the first lecture, which is wonderful. However, it seems, at least intuitively to me, that the markov_pi script and the explanations may be wrong. In my opinion, the code underestimates pi. What I did, is that I added one more loop and I used several values of delta. I see that as delta increases, pi tends to be lower and lower. I guess that a 'correct' mcmc should not underestimate the value, is that right? my code from pylab import * import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import random def markov_pi(N, delta): x, y = 1.0, 1.0 n_hits = 0 for i in range(N): del_x, del_y = random.uniform(-delta, delta), random.uniform(-delta, delta) if abs(x + del_x) < 1.0 and abs(y + del_y) < 1.0: x, y = x + del_x, y + del_y if x**2 + y**2 < 1.0: n_hits += 1 return n_hits n_runs = 100 n_trials = 4000 xpl = [] ypl = [] for d in range( 1,100 ): delta = d/float(10) mean = 0 for run in range(n_runs): res = 4.0 * markov_pi(n_trials, delta) / float(n_trials) mean += res mean /= float( n_runs ) xpl.append(delta) ypl.append(mean) plot(xpl, ypl) and the result figure ( x-axis: delta, y-axis: estimated pi)

Input.threadtitle: Is the markov python code correct? Underestimating pi
Input.posts:
Hi all, I just watched the first lecture, which is wonderful. However, it seems, at least intuitively to me, that the markov_pi script and the explanations may be wrong. In my opinion, the code underestimates pi. What I did, is that I added one more loop and I used several values of delta. I see that as delta increases, pi tends to be lower and lower. I guess that a 'correct' mcmc should not underestimate the value, is that right? my code from pylab import * import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import random def markov_pi(N, delta): x, y = 1.0, 1.0 n_hits = 0 for i in range(N): del_x, del_y = random.uniform(-delta, delta), random.uniform(-delta, delta) if abs(x + del_x) < 1.0 and abs(y + del_y) < 1.0: x, y = x + del_x, y + del_y if x**2 + y**2 < 1.0: n_hits += 1 return n_hits n_runs = 100 n_trials = 4000 xpl = [] ypl = [] for d in range( 1,100 ): delta = d/float(10) mean = 0 for run in range(n_runs): res = 4.0 * markov_pi(n_trials, delta) / float(n_trials) mean += res mean /= float( n_runs ) xpl.append(delta) ypl.append(mean) plot(xpl, ypl) and the result figure ( x-axis: delta, y-axis: estimated pi)
